title.rendered: Create a document and make notes on these four key elements: market conditions, competitive positioning, your ideal customers, your product offering, and pricing.

content.rendered:
• For example, your “battle environment” may be a market that is flush with competitors, while your “target enemy” may include a segmented, independent Buyer Persona.
  • Knowing each of these elements will help you choose a GtM strategy that will acquire, retain, and grow your customers in the most capital-efficient way.

title.rendered: Analyze your customer data to decide if you have lifetime value customers or a large client pool.

content.rendered:
• A sales-led strategy provides the personalization and assistance required to satisfy a lifetime value customer base.
  • A market-led strategy is best for a large client pool, where enough prospective clients exist to mitigate potential marketing-qualified lead leaking.

title.rendered: Analyze the uniqueness of your product within the market.

content.rendered: If you are providing a hyper-niche solution, a sales-led approach will work best.

title.rendered: Evaluate market conditions and competitor pricing.

content.rendered:
• Sales-led strategies can suffer in a competitive environment where businesses with more efficient CACs dictate product pricing.
  • Market-led strategies can take advantage of previous customer knowledge.

title.rendered: Establish a budget for customer acquisition costs (CAC).

content.rendered:
• Sales-led strategies have a high CAC and lifetime value customers need to recoup the cost of acquisition. 
  • A market-led strategy has a lower CAC.

title.rendered: Analyze your sales (sales-led) and marketing (market-led) teams to decide where your business is strongest.

content.rendered:
• For example, a sales-led strategy leverages your sales team to reach potential clients, so your sales team will need to be strong from start to finish.
  • A market-led strategy will require your marketing team to drive Marketing Qualified Leads.

title.rendered: Create a tactical plan for your go-to-market strategy that includes your customer acquisition process and channels.

content.rendered: Having a document that details your acquisition channels (SEO; email campaigns; social media like Facebook, Twitter, or LinkedIn; so on) and stages (for example: stranger > researcher > visitor > lead > established > well-established > promoter) will help you to choose the appropriate go-to-market strategy.
